texts.definition: Goals within games with rewards associated to their completion.
markups: <style="Definition">Goals within games with rewards associated to their completion.</style>

While players need to complete many goals in a game, not all are clearly described with how they should be completed nor what rewards they will give. <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> on the other hand are goals where both finishing requirements and rewards are well-known in advance.

The gameplay in roleplaying games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">The Elder Scrolls series</link></style> is structured around solving <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style>, some which are needed to finish the game and some which are optional. This also goes for action roleplaying games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>.

Games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Empires%20&%20Allies">Empires & Allies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ravenwood%20Fair">Ravenwood Fair</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombie%20Lane">Zombie Lane</link></style> on social media sites direct players efforts in games by providing several <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> players can work on in parallel.

Designing <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> consists of selecting goals, <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, and how players are made aware of them. Most goals can be used for <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> but some are more common than others: <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> (possibly to find <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race">Race</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style>. These goals can of course involve various types of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Elements">Game Elements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>, etc., depending on what type of goal is used, but <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style> is worth mentioning since they do not have any gameplay function besides that of the goal but can still have diegetic roles. While any type of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> can work, e.g. gaining <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, gaining <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> may be more suitable than in other contexts due to the diegetic social context. Another type of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> is to let players prove their <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>. While <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> may automatically be completed when certain requirements are met, players can be given an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style> and a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> by making the formal end of them be tied to activating <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style> of some sort.

While game systems can provide <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> directly to players, it can be done diegetically through <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> (including those that are <style="Link"><link="self-service-kiosks">Self-Service Kiosks</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tutorial%20Neighbors">Tutorial Neighbors</link></style>). By using <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NPCs">NPCs</link></style> that are connected to <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> this can linked to <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> and possibly <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>. An alternative in how to provide <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> is to let it be known through <style="Link"><link="gossip">Gossip</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eavesdropping">Eavesdropping</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> can be used to both make players aware of <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> and provide hints on how to solve ones they are engaged in.

Two main varieties of <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> exist, <style="Link"><link="main-quests">Main Quests</link></style> that needs to be completed to finish a game and optional <style="Link"><link="sidequests">Sidequests</link></style>. The gameplay of <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> can be made more <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex</link></style> by introducing <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> (potentially with <style="Link"><link="incompatible-goals">Incompatible Goals</link></style>), or subgoals (i.e. <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style> consisting of <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style>). They can be made easier through using <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style>. Adding <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> to failing <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> make the <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> into <style="Link"><link="committed-goals">Committed Goals</link></style> (as long as they are <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>), and thereby making the choice of accepting <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> considerations. Two other case, more specialized and both examples of <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>, are <style="Link"><link="companion-quests">Companion Quests</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="endgame-quests">Endgame Quests</link></style> which can be created for games with <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style> phases respectively.

<style="Link"><link="testing-achievements">Testing Achievements</link></style> are be linked to <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> to further encourage them to be completed, or to replay them in other ways.

Since it requires resources of varying kinds to develop <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> (e.g. to script them, provide game art, develop dialogue, etc.), an option is it to let players play them several times or, in the case of <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, let different players independently have the same <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style>. This creates <style="Link"><link="non-consistent-narration">Non-Consistent Narration</link></style> and makes it difficult to let the <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> affect the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>; <style="Link"><link="phasing">Phasing</link></style> is a partial solution to this for games with <style="Link"><link="mediated-gameplay">Mediated Gameplay</link></style>. An alternative is to use <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> to create variation and thereby a form of <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> in the <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> without having to develop completely new content resources for each possible <style="CurrentLink">Quest</style>.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> explicitly state the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> and the requirements associated with received them, they draw attention to the mechanical aspect of a game and thereby may work against <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Narrative%20Engrossment">Narrative Engrossment</link></style> and point out any problems with <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>. This is especially true for <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, and <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> may be necessary for these to be able to have <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> are typically handled through <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>, especially if there are optional ones or if one can have several available at the same time.

<style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> have many aspects related to <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> in games since they require providing players with intentions for tasks and planning what the effects of completing those tasks, as well as possibly creating <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> that provide the <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style>. They are also useful as basic elements to build <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style> tied to <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="adventures">Adventures</link></style> or even <style="Link"><link="campaigns">Campaigns</link></style> can be built around one or more <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style>. They are quite often started and ended through <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>, possibly combined with <style="Link"><link="quick-travel">Quick Travel</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style>. A common use of <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> in relation to <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> is to open up access to <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> when the <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> are active, or as part of the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> for completing them.

It is common to have <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> rather than ordinary <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> at the end of <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> in order to provide more satisfying finales.

Given that the designs of <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> include having planned how players are introduced to them, how they complete them, and what effects solving them would be, they are both <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. Since these link the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> of a game with how the <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> in it behave, <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> can be seen as a way of defining them and creating or steering their <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="goal-driven-personal-development">Goal-Driven Personal Development</link></style>. In this sense, they can lead to <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> for players regardless of what <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, if any, they provide.

<style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> can provide players with both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style> since they can observe their own progression and know what the requirements for completing them are. When <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> give players to clear direction where they should move in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> they lessen the reason for <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> by promoting <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals instead. Completing, or permanently failing to complete <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> are <style="Link"><link="closure-points">Closure Points</link></style>. While completing them typically provide clear <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> in how they provide <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> or advance the narration, failing <style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> can also give a <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> if they clearly show what effects the efforts had.

<style="CurrentLink">Quests</style> provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> when they are organized so that players are slowly exposed to the gameplay design of a game.

<style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="adventures">Adventures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="campaigns">Campaigns</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="closure-points">Closure Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="goal-driven-personal-development">Goal-Driven Personal Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="companion-quests">Companion Quests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="endgame-quests">Endgame Quests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="main-quests">Main Quests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race">Race</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-service-kiosks">Self-Service Kiosks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sidequests">Sidequests</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eavesdropping">Eavesdropping</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gossip">Gossip</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-consistent-narration">Non-Consistent Narration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="testing-achievements">Testing Achievements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tutorial%20Neighbors">Tutorial Neighbors</link></style>
